description: From Middle English abundaunce, habaundance, from Old French habundance, abondance, from Latin abundantia (“fullness, plenty”), from abundō (“to overflow”). Equivalent to abound +‎ -ance.

entries.meaning: A large quantity; many. [First attested around 1150 to 1350.]
examples: Synonyms: heap, load; see also Thesaurus:lot
Due to the abundance of art material, the class made a giant collage.
There is not a great abundance of time, so please don't dawdle.

entries.meaning: An overflowing fullness or ample sufficiency; profusion; copious supply; superfluity; plentifulness. [First attested around 1350 to 1470.]
examples: Synonyms: exuberance, copiousness, overflow, plenty, plenteousness, plenitude, plentitude; see also Thesaurus:excess

entries.meaning: Wealth; affluence; plentiful amount of resources. [First attested around 1350 to 1470.]
examples: Synonyms: riches, affluence, wealth; see also Thesaurus:wealth

entries.meaning: Frequency, amount, ratio of something within a given environment or sample. [First attested in the late 19th century.]
(card games) A bid to take nine or more tricks in solo whist. [First attested in the late 19th century.]
